Without treatment, which of the following is the most likely clinical course of this patient’s existing skin lesions?

choices.text: Slow increase in size and ulceration
Rapid increase in number and spread to the trunk

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This clinical course can occur with blistering skin disorders (e.g., pemphigus vulgaris, bullous pemphigoid, Steven Johnson syndrome) and pyogenic granuloma. Senile purpura lesions do not generally enlarge or ulcerate.

B) INCORRECT:

Certain viral exanthems (e.g., varicella, measles, rubella) and noninfectious skin diseases (e.g., erythema multiforme) can start in the extremities and spread rapidly to the trunk. New senile purpura can appear over time but the existing lesions do not increase in number rapidly. Moreover, senile purpura typically develops in the face, neck, and dorsal aspects of extremities rather than the trunk.

C) INCORRECT:

Senile purpura are not premalignant skin lesions. Examples of premalignant skin conditions include actinic keratosis and dysplastic nevi, both of which can occur in sun-exposed areas such as the neck and the dorsal surface of the hands and forearms. Actinic keratosis, however, appears as brownish papules or plaques (rather than macules) with fine white scaling of the overlying skin, and the lesions are typically less than 1 cm in size. Dysplastic nevi can have an irregular shape but would be expected to have poorly defined margins and variations in color.

D) CORRECT:

Senile purpura, which is a common benign dermatological condition among older individuals, manifests as dark purple macules with irregular edges in sun-exposed areas (e.g., face, neck, dorsal aspect of hands and forearms). The lesions are a result of damage to dermal connective tissues and blood vessels due to aging and chronic sun exposure causing blood vessels to rupture easily, resulting in purpura or ecchymoses. Senile purpura can recur but the existing lesions will resolve spontaneously over a few weeks without treatment. In some cases, mild brownish discoloration may persist as a result of hemosiderin deposition.

E) INCORRECT:

These characteristics are not features of senile purpura and apply to conditions such as tinea versicolor and leprosy. Senile purpura typically resolves with brownish discoloration or without any permanent discoloration.
questions.hint: This patient's uniformly dark purple skin lesions with an irregular shape but well-defined margins are most likely senile purpura.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old female marathon runner presents with a lesion on the heel of her right foot that has been growing larger for the past 6 months and is moderately painful when she exercises. She is otherwise healthy.
Examination reveals a 1-cm rough plaque on the heel of her right foot (figure). When the skin is examined with a magnifying glass, tiny punctate hemorrhages seem embedded in the plaque, with distortion of the normal skin lines. The rest of the patient’s skin examination is normal.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The most likely diagnosis in this patient is a plantar wart (verruca plantaris). Plantar warts are caused by specific strains of the human papillomavirus and typically manifest as endophytic verrucous plaques on the plantar surface of the foot, with a characteristic dry, rough surface that interrupts the normal skin lines and pinpoint hemorrhagic macules representing thrombosed capillaries. Plantar warts are sometimes symptomatic, causing discomfort during ambulation.

Although warts may resolve spontaneously, treatment is reasonable if the wart is causing symptoms, if there is frequent trauma to the site of the wart, or if the wart is in a genital or peri-orificial location. Single treatment of warts has modest therapeutic benefit; therefore, combination treatment and repeat treatments are often necessary.

There are two fundamental strategies for treating warts:
• Destructive methods, which include paring of the wart, liquid nitrogen/cryosurgery, laser therapy, topical salicylic acid, fluorouracil cream, cantharidin, topical retinoid creams, intralesional bleomycin or other chemotherapy, and surgical excision.
• Immunotherapy methods, which include intralesional Candida antigen, imiquimod cream, and contact sensitization.

Office-based paring followed by liquid nitrogen therapy and in-home salicylic acid treatment between office visits is a common first-line approach to treating plantar warts.

Key learning point: First-line therapy for a symptomatic plantar wart is cryotherapy or salicylic acid.

B) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin gel (or in some cases oral erythromycin) is used to treat a distinct, common rash on the foot called pitted keratolysis, which is caused by bacterial infection. The hallmark of this rash is plantar skin maceration with sharply demarcated vermiform pits and a strong, fruity odor.

C) INCORRECT:

Orthotics might be appropriate for a long-distance runner with a callus. However, calluses are readily distinguishable from plantar warts because they accentuate, rather than replace, normal skin lines over bony pressure points. Calluses are caused by repetitive trauma, which induces protective hyperkeratosis that preserves the skin lines and accentuates normal sole anatomy. Plantar warts interrupt the normal skin lines on the foot, as shown in the figure in this case. In addition, the lesion in this case is not in an area common to calluses.

D) INCORRECT:

Surgical removal is occasionally considered for warts at other sites but is avoided for plantar warts because of the risk of scars, which can be chronically painful at this site.

E) INCORRECT:

Econazole cream would be an excellent choice for treatment of tinea pedis, a superficial fungal infection, but this patient’s presentation is not consistent with that diagnosis. Tinea pedis is an erythematous scaly eruption on the plantar aspect of the foot, often involving the interdigital webspaces with maceration. This diagnosis can be confirmed by performing microscopic analysis of skin scrapings in 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution, thereby revealing branching hyphal elements. Long-standing tinea pedis may result in concomitant toenail infection, marked by yellow, dystrophic nails with subungual hyperkeratosis.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman presents with hyperpigmentation in a masklike distribution over her face (figure). She reports that the discoloration initially appeared on her cheeks around 2 years ago and then spread around her upper lip, eyes, and onto her forehead. She had no preceding rash and has never had a similar eruption. She is otherwise healthy, and her only medications are a combined oral contraceptive pill and a multivitamin.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lentigines are acquired hyperpigmented macules and patches related to increased melanocyte-derived melanin production. However, lesions associated with this diagnosis are usually much smaller than the patches on the upper lip of this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Lentigo maligna, a subtype of melanoma in situ on the face, manifests with irregular borders and color variegation. Even pigmentation and symmetric distribution on the face would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Postinflammatory hyperpigmentation refers to hyperpigmentation at sites of previous inflammation or trauma. The lack of antecedent rash or trauma in this patient makes this diagnosis less likely.

D) CORRECT:

Melasma is a pigmentary disorder characterized by evenly hyperpigmented macules and patches on the face, often affecting the malar cheeks, nose, upper lip, and lower forehead. Women are affected by melasma much more often than men, and onset is usually after puberty. The etiology is unclear. Known risk factors include hyperestrogenism from pregnancy and oral contraceptive use, exposure to ultraviolet radiation, and a positive family history.

Treatment of melasma centers on careful photoprotection. Affected patients should use a broad-spectrum tinted sunscreen to block ultraviolet and visible light, both of which have been linked to worsening disease, and should be encouraged to wear a wide-brim hat. Patients may try compounded creams containing hydroquinone, although they should be counseled to avoid long-term use given the risk for paradoxically worsening hyperpigmentation (exogenous ochronosis). Other treatments for melasma include azelaic acid, kojic acid, chemical peels, fractionated laser therapy, and oral tranexamic acid. Pregnancy-induced melasma is frequently self-limited and may resolve after delivery.

Key learning point: Melasma — an acquired disorder of hyperpigmentation on the cheeks, forehead, nose, and upper lip — is associated with states of elevated estrogen, such as pregnancy and oral contraceptive use.

E) INCORRECT:

Nevus of Ota represents facial dermal melanocytosis that is usually seen at birth but is occasionally noted after puberty or pregnancy. It often has a blue-gray color because the pigment is dermal rather than epidermal.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with asymptomatic hyperpigmentation around her neck and in both axillae (figure). She first noticed it about 3 years ago and is bothered by its appearance. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. Her BMI is 32.
What is the most likely underlying condition associated with these skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acanthosis nigricans is a skin disorder characterized by symmetric, hyperpigmented, velvety plaques on flexural areas (e.g., neck, axillae, groin). It is usually asymptomatic but may also be pruritic.

Acanthosis nigricans is commonly associated with insulin resistance or type 2 diabetes. The exact pathophysiology is unknown but may involve the stimulation of insulin-like growth factor receptors and tyrosine kinase receptors on keratinocytes and fibroblasts. Given that obesity is a risk factor for insulin resistance, acanthosis nigricans may also occur in people with obesity.

Acanthosis nigricans has been associated with endocrinopathies such as hypercortisolism and growth hormone excess. Other less common associations with acanthosis nigricans include use of certain medications (e.g., niacin) and malignancy, especially in people who have extensive and sudden onset of acanthosis nigricans.

Key learning point: Acanthosis nigricans appears as hyperpigmented, velvety plaques, typically in flexural areas, and is commonly associated with insulin resistance.

B) INCORRECT:

Atopic dermatitis may cause thickening and hyperpigmentation of the skin — called lichen simplex chronicus — when the rash is chronically scratched. Unlike acanthosis nigricans, lichen simplex chronicus tends to be pruritic and to have associated scaling and excoriation; in addition, the axillae would be an atypical location for atopic dermatitis. Although atopic dermatitis can lead to lichen simplex chronicus, it is not classically associated with acanthosis nigricans.

C) INCORRECT:

Although acanthosis nigricans has been associated with endocrinopathies such as hypercortisolism and growth hormone excess, it is not typically associated with thyroid disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Nutritional deficiencies, such as zinc deficiency, can manifest as skin rashes. The typical findings of zinc deficiency are dry, scaly, sharply demarcated plaques on the face or groin. Rashes associated with zinc deficiency can resolve rapidly with zinc supplementation. Acanthosis nigricans is not specifically associated with zinc deficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Fungal infections, such as tinea corporis, manifest as annular (ring-shaped), scaling plaques. Tinea corporis is caused by a dermatophyte infection and is not associated with acanthosis nigricans.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old girl presents for evaluation of skin lesions that have slowly increased in number during the past month. The lesions are not painful, but the girl frequently picks at them. She has no significant medical history, and her immunizations are up to date.
Skin examination reveals several 3- to 5-mm flesh-colored papules with a rough texture predominantly on the patient's feet and hands with a larger lesion on the distal end of her thumb (figure).
What is the most appropriate first-line therapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Podophyllotoxin is effective on mucosal surfaces and is therefore used to treat genital warts. Few data support its use for nongenital warts.

B) INCORRECT:

Imiquimod cream is indicated for genital, not common, warts. It is also used to treat actinic keratosis (scaly hyperkeratotic papules or patches in sun-exposed areas, primarily in adults, that represent precursor lesions to squamous-cell carcinoma) and superficial basal-cell carcinoma (red, pink, or flesh-colored pearly papules, ulcerated lesions, or scar-like lesions in sun-exposed areas, primarily in adults or in children with basal-cell nevus syndrome).

C) INCORRECT:

The HPV vaccine prevents infection with the HPV serotypes implicated in anogenital warts and cervical cancer (6, 11, 16, and 18) but not the serotypes that cause common warts (cutaneous warts, of the hands and feet). In addition, the HPV vaccine is approved for use starting at age 9 and would not be appropriate in this young child.

D) CORRECT:

Common warts (verruca vulgaris) appear as flesh-colored, wide-based papules with punctate black discolorations (dilated vessels) and a grainy (verrucous) texture. They are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV), which is transmitted through skin-to-skin contact or infected fomites. The HPV serotypes that cause common warts are distinct from those that cause genital warts.

About two-thirds of common warts resolve on their own without any therapy. There are many available therapies; however, pooled data from six randomized controlled trials showed cure rates of 75% with salicylic acid versus 48% with placebo. There was no clear evidence to suggest that other therapies, such as cryotherapy, had higher cure rates or fewer adverse effects than salicylic acid. Salicylic acid is a particularly good first-line option for children because it is not painful; however, it does often require at least 3 months of daily use.

Key learning point: The most appropriate first-line therapy for common warts is topical salicylic acid.

E) INCORRECT:

There is no clear evidence to suggest that other therapies, such as cryotherapy, had higher cure rates or fewer adverse effects than salicylic acid.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old girl presents with a lesion on the heel of her right foot that has been growing larger for the past 6 months and is moderately painful when she runs and plays soccer. She is otherwise healthy.
Examination reveals a 1-cm rough plaque on the heel of her right foot (figure). When the skin is examined with a magnifying glass, tiny punctate hemorrhages seem embedded in the plaque. The rest of the patient’s skin examination is normal.
Which one of the following treatments is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Econazole cream would be an excellent choice for treatment of tinea pedis, a superficial fungal infection, but this patient’s presentation is not consistent with that diagnosis. Tinea pedis is an erythematous scaly eruption on the plantar aspect of the foot, often involving the interdigital webspaces with maceration. This diagnosis can be confirmed by performing microscopic analysis of skin scrapings in 10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution, thereby revealing branching hyphal elements. Long-standing tinea pedis may result in concomitant toenail infection, marked by yellow, dystrophic nails with subungual hyperkeratosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Orthotics might be appropriate for athletes with a callus. However, calluses are readily distinguishable from plantar warts because they accentuate, rather than replace, normal skin lines over bony pressure points. Calluses are caused by repetitive trauma, which induces protective hyperkeratosis that preserves the skin lines and accentuates normal sole anatomy. Plantar warts interrupt the normal skin lines on the foot, as shown in the figure in this case. In addition, the lesion in this case is not in an area common to calluses.

C) INCORRECT:

Imiquimod cream, whose primary indication is the treatment of genital warts, is not a highly effective treatment for warts in nonmucosal sites.

D) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin gel (or in some cases oral erythromycin) is used to treat a distinct, common rash on the foot called pitted keratolysis, which is caused by bacterial infection. The hallmark of this rash is plantar skin maceration with sharply demarcated vermiform pits and a strong, fruity odor.

E) CORRECT:

The most likely diagnosis in this patient is a plantar wart (verruca plantaris). Plantar warts are caused by specific strains of the human papillomavirus and typically manifest as endophytic or exophytic verrucous plaques on the plantar surface of the foot, with a characteristic dry, rough surface that interrupts the normal skin lines and pinpoint hemorrhagic macules representing thrombosed capillaries. Plantar warts are sometimes symptomatic, causing discomfort during ambulation.

Although warts may resolve spontaneously, treatment is reasonable if the wart is causing symptoms, if there is frequent trauma to the site of the wart, or if the wart is in a sensitive location. Single treatment of warts has modest therapeutic benefit; therefore, combination treatment and repeat treatments are often necessary.

There are two fundamental strategies for treating warts:

• Destructive methods, which include paring of the wart, liquid nitrogen/cryosurgery, laser therapy, topical salicylic acid, fluorouracil cream, cantharidin, topical retinoid creams, intralesional bleomycin or other chemotherapy, and surgical excision. Of note, surgical excision is not recommended as the wart often recurs due to microscopic extension beyond the visible portion.
• Immunotherapy methods, which include intralesional Candida antigen, imiquimod cream, and contact sensitization.

Office-based paring followed by liquid nitrogen therapy and in-home salicylic acid treatment between office visits is a common first-line approach to treating plantar warts. Because liquid nitrogen can be a painful treatment, some children will opt for salicylic acid, which is slower but painless. It is important to allow a child who is 8 years or older to participate in the treatment decision. Cryotherapy and other painful therapies should be deferred in younger patients to prevent psychological trauma and ongoing fear of doctors.

Key learning point: First-line therapy for a symptomatic plantar wart is cryotherapy or salicylic acid.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the office by her mother because of skin bumps on her right hand. Her mother took her to the doctor when she first noticed them 2 years ago. No treatment was given at that time and the doctor reassured her that they would resolve on their own. However, the patient is now being made fun of at school because of the lesions on her hand, and her mother is worried that the lesions or treatment might result in permanent scarring. The patient has otherwise been well and her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears scared. A photograph of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical administration of fluorouracil (FU) can be used in patients with common warts who have not responded to first-line treatment. However, topical FU is associated with multiple side effects (e.g., erythema, dryness, burning sensation), and its safety and effectiveness have not been established for pediatric use, making a different intervention more appropriate for this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulsed dye laser therapy is a second-line treatment option for patients with common warts. Given the high cost, low availability, and side effects of the procedure (e.g., skin discoloration, scarring, pain), pulsed dye laser therapy is reserved for patients who have not responded to first-line therapy. This patient has not yet received any treatment; therefore, another treatment option is indicated at this point.

C) INCORRECT:

Intralesional bleomycin injection may be indicated for patients with common warts that are refractory to first-line treatment. However, this injection is not recommended for immunosuppressed individuals, pregnant women, or children because of the risk of systemic absorption of bleomycin (a chemotherapeutic agent).

D) CORRECT:

Topical salicylic acid is one of the first-line treatment options for the management of common warts in patients who present with associated pain, functional impairment, or discomfort. The benefits of this treatment option include high efficacy and availability, low cost, painless application, and minimal side effects, all of which make topical salicylic acid a safe option for wart removal in pediatric patients. Topical salicylic acid can also be combined with other first-line treatment options, such as cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen, for a faster and more effective therapeutic response.

E) INCORRECT:

Surgical excision (e.g., curettage) is a second-line treatment option for the management of common warts. This option is reserved for patients who have not responded to first-line therapy or who request the immediate removal of warts. However, surgery is associated with an increased risk of scarring, infection, and wart recurrence, which limits its use in clinical practice.
questions.hint: This patient's partially confluent, hyperkeratotic papules with a rough surface are consistent with common warts, which are caused by human papillomavirus.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to the office because his wife is worried about lesions on his face which she first noticed 4 months ago. The patient says he feels well and that the lesions do not bother him. He has a 10-year history of hypertension. His family history is unremarkable. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and enalapril. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows two soft, painless, 5-mm papules on the right cheek; a photograph of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Seborrheic keratosis is a benign, slow-growing lesion that is commonly seen in older individuals. For asymptomatic lesions, such as the one seen here, treatment is generally not necessary and reassurance with follow-up is sufficient. If atypical features are present (e.g., asymmetry, rapid change or growth, ulceration) or if the diagnosis is unclear, a biopsy may be indicated. Treatment with cryotherapy, laser therapy, or surgical excision is appropriate for cosmetic removal or if the lesion becomes symptomatic (e.g., pruritic, painful, or bleeds easily).

In patients with the sudden appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses, known as the Leser-Trélat sign, further investigation is necessary because of this feature's association with malignancies such as lung cancer and gastrointestinal cancer.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical salicylic acid is the first-line treatment for warts, which can manifest as soft papules on the face (i.e., flat warts or verruca plana). However, flat warts are more common in younger individuals and they are usually flesh-colored, smooth, and flat, whereas this elderly patient's lesion is darkly pigmented and has a “stuck-on” appearance. Salicylic acid treatment is not recommended for seborrheic keratosis.
Image Description:

Partially confluent, hyperkeratotic papules with a rough surface are seen on the dorsal surface of the hand at the level of the metacarpophalangeal joint

C) INCORRECT:

A shave biopsy might be indicated to rule out malignancy in patients with pigmented skin lesions with atypical features (e.g., size > 6 mm; a recent change in shape, size, or color; irregular borders; asymmetry). This patient, however, has a small (5 mm), asymptomatic lesion that has not changed much over the past 4 months and has a waxy, “stuck-on” appearance, all of which are characteristic of seborrheic keratosis.

D) INCORRECT:

An excisional biopsy is indicated for pigmented lesions if there is suspicion for melanoma. According to the ABCDE rule for melanoma, a biopsy should be considered if the lesion is > 6 mm in diameter, asymmetric, has color variegation, irregular borders, or recent change in size, shape, or color. This patient's lesion has a waxy, “stuck-on” appearance characteristic of seborrheic keratosis, for which biopsy is not routinely indicated.
Image Description:

Upper back

An asymmetrical lesion approx. 16 mm in diameter is visible.

This lesion fulfills the A (asymmetry), B (border irregularity), C (color variegation), and D (diameter > 6 mm) criteria for melanoma. The diagnosis should be confirmed by performing a full-thickness excisional biopsy.

E) INCORRECT:

Cryotherapy is the most common treatment for seborrheic keratosis. However, cryotherapy is indicated in symptomatic lesions or if the patient requests treatment for cosmetic reasons, which is not the case here.
questions.hint: The photograph shows two sharply demarcated and darkly pigmented papules that have a “stuck-on” appearance. This type of lesion in an older individual is characteristic of seborrheic keratosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of multiple red spots on his trunk. He first noticed these several months ago, and some appear to have increased in size. One day ago, he scratched one of these spots, and it bled for several minutes. A photograph of the lesions is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bartonella henselae infections cause bacillary angiomatosis, which manifests with vascular proliferations that bleed with trauma, like the lesions seen in this patient. Although the lesions of bacillary angiomatosis can manifest with a papular appearance, they also commonly manifest as nodular, pedunculated, or verrucous lesions. In addition, this condition usually develops in patients infected with HIV, of which there is no indication here.

B) CORRECT:

Cherry angiomas are benign, vascular proliferations that commonly develop in adult patients. The diagnosis is typically made based on the clinical appearance of multiple, bright red, dome-shaped papules on the trunk and upper extremities that bleed with trauma and usually blanch with pressure. These lesions manifest more frequently with age and do not regress. Histologically, they are characterized by dilated interconnecting capillaries within the papillary dermis. No treatment is necessary unless lesions become bothersome (e.g., if they catch on clothing, bleed frequently, or are cosmetically unappealing). Options for removal include electrodessication, laser ablation, and surgical excision.

C) INCORRECT:

Strawberry angiomas are benign, vascular proliferations that may bleed with trauma, like the lesions seen in this patient. However, strawberry angiomas usually develop in the first weeks of life on the head or neck and then involute by 5–8 years of age.
Image Description:

Dome-shaped, crusted, red nodule on the lower left eyelid of a child. Two smaller nodules can be seen above the left eye and on the forehead.

These lesions are also referred to as strawberry hemangiomas and are usually located on the head and neck region.

D) INCORRECT:

Seborrheic keratoses are common, benign skin proliferations with a characteristic greasy, stuck-on appearance. Like this patient's papules, seborrheic keratoses typically develop as multiple lesions on the trunk of adult patients. However, they also commonly develop on the head and extremities. Additionally, these lesions are more commonly brown, tan, or skin-colored and do not bleed with trauma as readily as the lesions seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photograph of the upper body of an older adult (dorsal view)

Multiple sharply demarcated, darkly pigmented hyperkeratotic papules are visible. The papules have a characteristic stuck on appearance.

Seborrheic keratosis is a benign skin tumor that arises from keratinocytes and is common in older adults.

E) INCORRECT:

Pyogenic granulomas are benign, vascular proliferations that bleed with trauma, like the lesions seen in this patient. However, this condition typically manifests as a solitary papule at sites of trauma (particularly on the face, hands, or mucous membranes), unlike the multiple lesions seen here. Moreover, pyogenic granulomas are more prevalent among children, young adults, and pregnant women.
Image Description:

An ovoid, distinctly erythematous, pedunculated papule that is surrounded by a zone of hyperplastic and hyperkeratotic epidermis (acanthosis) is visible in the center of the photo.
questions.hint: This middle-aged man presents with bright red papules that bleed with traumatic rupture, which suggests that the lesions are highly vascular.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother because of a dark red mass on his left thumb. The lesion appeared after his cat scratched him on the left thumb and has rapidly increased in size over the past 2 months. It is not painful, but the lesion bled profusely once when he accidentally bumped his hand on a desk. He is otherwise healthy and receives no other medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the left upper extremity shows a solitary 2-cm lesion on the interphalangeal joint of the thumb; a photograph of the lesion is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A cherry hemangioma can manifest as a painless, red lesion that may bleed profusely after trauma. However, cherry hemangiomas are usually seen in adults older than 30 years of age and rarely occur on the hands. Moreover, multiple, smaller (0.1–0.4 cm) lesions rather than a single nodule are typically seen.
Image Description:

Multiple well-demarcated cherry-red papules are distributed on the skin.

This appearance is characteristic of cherry angiomas.

B) CORRECT:

Pyogenic granuloma (PG) is a benign, vascular tumor characterized by rapid growth and a tendency to bleed profusely after minor trauma. PG typically manifests as a painless, red papule or nodule and often develops at sites of skin injury on the face or hands, as seen here. The exact cause is unknown. Young men and pregnant women are commonly affected. Diagnosis is based on clinical findings but a histopathological confirmation can help to rule out malignant tumors. Surgical excision is the preferred method of treatment because it reduces the recurrence rate. Other methods of treatment include laser therapy, cryotherapy, intralesional steroid injections, and topical therapies (e.g., beta-blockers).

C) INCORRECT:

A glomus tumor can manifest as a red-purple nodule on the fingers. However, glomus tumors are typically located on the nail bed or the palm and are associated with severe paroxysmal pain, tenderness, and cold sensitivity. Furthermore, a glomus tumor does not usually bleed following minor trauma or develop at the site of an injury.
Image Description:

A solitary vascularized subcutaneous nodule is visible on the pulp of the little finger of the left hand.

D) INCORRECT:

Kaposi sarcoma can manifest with a painless, red-brown nodule. However, multiple lesions on the lower legs, chest, and/or mucous membranes are typically seen. Moreover, Kaposi sarcoma is typically seen in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., individuals with HIV, organ transplant recipients) and does not usually lead to profuse bleeding following minor trauma.
Image Description:

A mixture of dark red macules, papules, and plaques are distributed asymmetrically on the skin.

These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma (caused by human herpesvirus 8).

E) INCORRECT:

A keloid scar typically develops at the site of a wound 3–12 months after the injury, similar to what is seen in this patient, who was scratched by a cat 6 months ago. However, a keloid scar consists of brownish-red scar tissue with a claw-like appearance that grows beyond the boundaries of the injury, unlike what is seen here. Furthermore, in contrast to this patient's presentation, a keloid scar is usually painful, pruritic, and does not bleed following minor trauma.
Image Description:

The left earlobe (lobule) bears a well-defined lesion that extends well beyond the boundary of the initial defect (most likely an ear piercing).
questions.hint: This condition typically develops following skin trauma.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman presents with hyperpigmentation in a masklike distribution over her face (figure). She reports that the discoloration initially appeared on her cheeks around 2 years ago and then spread around her upper lip, eyes, and onto her forehead. She had no preceding rash and has never had a similar eruption. She is otherwise healthy, and her only medications are a combined oral contraceptive pill and a multivitamin. What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lentigines are acquired hyperpigmented macules and patches related to increased melanocyte-derived melanin production. However, lesions associated with this diagnosis are usually much smaller than the patches on the upper lip of this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Lentigo maligna, a subtype of melanoma in situ on the face, manifests with irregular borders and color variegation. Even pigmentation and symmetric distribution on the face would not be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Postinflammatory hyperpigmentation refers to hyperpigmentation at sites of previous inflammation or trauma. The lack of antecedent rash or trauma in this patient makes this diagnosis less likely.

D) CORRECT:

Melasma is a pigmentary disorder characterized by evenly hyperpigmented macules and patches on the face, often affecting the malar cheeks, nose, upper lip, and lower forehead. Women are affected by melasma much more often than men, and onset is usually after puberty. The etiology is unclear. Known risk factors include hyperestrogenism from pregnancy and oral contraceptive use, exposure to ultraviolet radiation, and a positive family history.

Treatment of melasma centers on careful photoprotection. Affected patients should use a broad-spectrum tinted sunscreen to block ultraviolet and visible light, both of which have been linked to worsening disease, and should be encouraged to wear a wide-brim hat. Patients may try compounded creams containing hydroquinone, although they should be counseled to avoid long-term use given the risk for paradoxically worsening hyperpigmentation (exogenous ochronosis). Other treatments for melasma include azelaic acid, kojic acid, chemical peels, fractionated laser therapy, and oral tranexamic acid. Pregnancy-induced melasma is frequently self-limited and may resolve after delivery.

Key learning point: Melasma — an acquired disorder of hyperpigmentation on the cheeks, forehead, nose, and upper lip — is associated with states of elevated estrogen, such as pregnancy and oral contraceptive use.

E) INCORRECT:

Nevus of Ota represents facial dermal melanocytosis that is usually seen at birth but is occasionally noted after puberty or pregnancy. It often has a blue-gray color because the pigment is dermal rather than epidermal.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to the office for an annual health maintenance examination. She feels well. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 79 kg (174 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Examination shows a skin rash over both axillae. A photograph of her left axilla is shown. This patient's skin finding is most likely associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, which manifests with a symmetrical, thickened, and hyperpigmented rash. However, the rash typically occurs in areas of the skin exposed to the sunlight (e.g., face, neck, hands) rather than in the axillae, as seen here. Moreover, further symptoms of pellagra, such as vomiting, diarrhea, atrophic glossitis, and neurological symptoms are absent in this patient. Niacin deficiency is not associated with acanthosis nigricans.

Pellagra and acanthosis nigricans can both manifest with a collar around the neck; also referred to as Casal necklace in the case of pellagra. However, the skin in niacin deficiency looks sun-burnt rather than velvety as seen here.
Image Description:

There are symmetrical, hyperpigmented, hyperkeratotic plaques on sun-exposed areas of the chest (Casal necklace), shoulders, face, hands, and arms.

This is the typical dermatological manifestation of pellagra. Dermatitis is one of the “4 D's of pellagra” alongside diarrhea, dementia, and death.

B) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal malignancies can manifest with acanthosis nigricans. However, if this skin finding occurs in association with a malignancy, such as paraneoplastic syndrome, it is characterized by rapid onset, a verrucous or papulous surface, and involvement of atypical sites (e.g., palms, soles, or mucous membranes), which is not the case in this patient. Moreover, malignant acanthosis nigricans is associated with gastric adenocarcinoma, not gastric malignant lymphoma. Lastly, gastric cancer is rare in young adults and this woman has no signs of gastrointestinal malignancy such as weight loss, anemia, abdominal discomfort, or melena.
Image Description:

Hyperpigmentation, hyperkeratosis, and numerous skin tags (papillomatosis) are visible on the right axilla.

These findings are consistent with acanthosis nigricans.

C) INCORRECT:

Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease) presents with hyperpigmented skin lesions caused by the stimulant effects of excess ACTH on the melanocytes which produce melanin (bronze disease). Unlike the skin finding in this patient, the hyperpigmentation in Addison disease is typically generalized and often involves the palm creases or oral mucosa. Instead of obesity, patients with Addison disease present with weight loss and anorexia due to hypocortisolism. Lastly, the absence of other symptoms such as hypotension and intestinal complaints (nausea, vomiting, and/or diarrhea), make Addison disease unlikely.

D) CORRECT:

Acanthosis nigricans is commonly seen in disorders characterized by insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia (e.g., polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), obesity, diabetes mellitus, acromegaly). Elevated levels of insulin stimulate keratinocyte and dermal fibroblast proliferation via interaction with insulin-like growth factor 1, resulting in epidermal hyperplasia and plaque-like lesions. In addition, insulin resistance in PCOS is responsible for hyperandrogenism (leading to acne, hirsutism) and anovulation (causing amenorrhea and impaired fertility).

Similar skin changes can be caused by obesity alone, in which case the disorder is referred to as pseudoacanthosis nigricans.

E) INCORRECT:

Pregnancy is associated with hyperpigmentation due to increased melanocyte-stimulating hormone produced by the placenta. Although the axillae may be affected, hyperpigmentation of the linea alba, the nipples, areola, and the face (i.e., melasma) are far more common. Moreover, the hyperpigmented macules and patches often seen during pregnancy are not thickened and velvety as seen here. Pregnancy is not associated with acanthosis nigricans.
Image Description:

Hyperpigmented brown, irregularly shaped patches are visible on both sides of the upper and lower cutaneous lip.

These features are characteristic of melasma, which typically has a centrofacial distribution.
questions.hint: The picture shows acanthosis nigricans, a skin condition that manifests with thickened, velvety, hyperpigmented plaques and most frequently involves intertriginous sites such as the axillae or the neck.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with asymptomatic hyperpigmentation around her neck and in both axillae (figure). She first noticed it about 3 years ago and is bothered by its appearance. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. Her BMI is 32 kg/m2. What is the most likely underlying condition associated with these skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Acanthosis nigricans is a skin disorder characterized by symmetric, hyperpigmented, velvety plaques on flexural areas (e.g., neck, axillae, groin). It is usually asymptomatic but may also be pruritic.

Acanthosis nigricans is commonly associated with insulin resistance or type 2 diabetes. The exact pathophysiology is unknown but may involve the stimulation of insulin-like growth factor receptors and tyrosine kinase receptors on keratinocytes and fibroblasts. Given that obesity is a risk factor for insulin resistance, acanthosis nigricans may also occur in people with obesity.

Acanthosis nigricans has been associated with endocrinopathies such as hypercortisolism and growth hormone excess. Other less common associations with acanthosis nigricans include use of certain medications (e.g., niacin) and malignancy, especially in people who have extensive and sudden onset of acanthosis nigricans.

Key learning point: Acanthosis nigricans appears as hyperpigmented, velvety plaques, typically in flexural areas, and is commonly associated with insulin resistance.

B) INCORRECT:

Atopic dermatitis may cause thickening and hyperpigmentation of the skin — called lichen simplex chronicus — when the rash is chronically scratched. Unlike acanthosis nigricans, lichen simplex chronicus tends to be pruritic and to have associated scaling and excoriation; in addition, the axillae would be an atypical location for atopic dermatitis. Although atopic dermatitis can lead to lichen simplex chronicus, it is not classically associated with acanthosis nigricans.

C) INCORRECT:

Although acanthosis nigricans has been associated with endocrinopathies such as hypercortisolism and growth hormone excess, it is not typically associated with thyroid disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Nutritional deficiencies, such as zinc deficiency, can manifest as skin rashes. The typical findings of zinc deficiency are dry, scaly, sharply demarcated plaques on the face or groin. Rashes associated with zinc deficiency can resolve rapidly with zinc supplementation. Acanthosis nigricans is not specifically associated with zinc deficiency.

E) INCORRECT:

Fungal infections, such as tinea corporis, manifest as annular (ring-shaped), scaling plaques. Tinea corporis is caused by a dermatophyte infection and is not associated with acanthosis nigricans.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 1-month history of a painless, nonpruritic skin lesion on her right thigh. She initially thought it was an insect bite, but it has slowly increased in size over the past few weeks. Her temperature is 36.7°C, pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 128/76 mm Hg. On examination, there is a 0.8-cm hyperpigmented papule. When the lesion is squeezed, the surface retracts inward. A photograph of the lesion is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Common warts (verruca vulgaris) are skin-colored, rough, scaly papules or plaques with a hyperkeratotic surface. They are most commonly located on the hands, feet, and/or knees and dimpling would not be expected.

B) INCORRECT:

Seborrheic keratosis appears as multiple, sharply demarcated, darkly pigmented papules or plaques that have a greasy, wax-like, and stuck-on appearance. They are most common in older adults and are primarily located on the trunk, hands, forearms, and face. Dimpling would not be expected.

C) CORRECT:

Dermatofibroma is a benign skin condition characterized by fibroblast proliferation, which leads to the development of small (3–10 mm in diameter), skin-colored, or brown fibrous nodules, most commonly on the lower extremities. Patients are typically asymptomatic and require no treatment. Surgical excision may be considered for cosmetic reasons, symptomatic lesions, or suspicion of malignancy.

Key learning point: Dermatofibroma is a benign, firm, hyperpigmented nodule that often shows a central dimple when pinched and most commonly occurs on the lower extremities.

D) INCORRECT:

Actinic keratosis is a precancerous skin lesion that typically occurs in individuals with light skin over the age of 50 years. The lesion is initially small with a rough, sandpaper-like surface, that grows slowly in size and becomes erythematous and scaly. The rapid appearance of this patient's skin lesion and the dimple sign are suggestive of another etiology.

E) INCORRECT:

A dysplastic nevus is an atypical mole that is assessed based on the ABCDE criteria. It is typically an evolving lesion with an asymmetric shape, irregular borders, inconsistent color, and diameter that is usually > 6 mm in size. The short history of and dimpling sign in this patient's skin lesion is suggestive of another etiology.
questions.hint: This benign skin lesion that exhibits a positive dimple sign (squeezing leads to an inward retraction of the surface) can occur after insect bites or trauma, but can also develop spontaneously.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 3-month history of a painless skin lesion on his neck. He reports that the lesion has gradually become darker and is sometimes itchy. He has also noticed a similar lesion on his lower back. He is a retired gardener and has a 40-year history of smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily. His temperature is 36.7°C, pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 123/78 mm Hg. On examination, there is a 0.8-cm hyperpigmented papule on his neck and a 0.6-cm hyperpigmented papule on his lower back, both with a greasy and wax-like appearance. A photograph of the neck lesion is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lentigo maligna (LM) is a precancerous skin lesion caused by long-term exposure to sunlight. While this patient's risk of developing malignant skin lesions is increased, LM manifests as an irregularly shaped, dark macule, unlike the sharply demarcated nodules seen in this patient. Since one of this patient's lesions is on skin that is not sun-exposed (lower back), this diagnosis is very unlikely.

B) INCORRECT:

A compound nevus is a benign skin lesion similar in appearance to common moles but usually lighter in color. The fact that it consists of a central raised area surrounded by a flat patch of pigmented skin makes it similar to this patient's lesion, but the dark pigmentation and waxy appearance, in this case, are more suggestive of a different diagnosis.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's lesions are consistent with seborrheic keratosis (SK), which often appears as multiple darkly pigmented, clearly demarcated papules or plaques that have a greasy, wax-like appearance. SKs typically develop on exposed body parts such as the hands, arms, trunk, head, and neck, and therefore are more prone to irritation, bleeding, and/or pruritus. Although these lesions are generally benign, the sudden development of multiple SKs may indicate an underlying malignancy (referred to as the Leser-Trélat sign).

Key learning point: Seborrheic keratosis presents as well-demarcated, greasy, wax-like, hyperpigmented papules or plaques, most commonly on the trunk, head, neck, or extremities, and is a benign skin lesion.
Image Description:

Trunk of a patient

Multiple, slightly raised plaques, with varying degrees of pigmentation are visible.

D) INCORRECT:

Actinic keratosis is a UV-induced precancerous skin lesion that initially presents with a sandpaper-like texture and progresses to erythematous, scaly lesions. While this patient's work as a gardener places him at increased risk of developing actinic keratosis, the lesions' greasy, wax-like appearance and the location of one on a body part that is not typically sun-exposed (lower back) make this diagnosis unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

A dysplastic nevus is a benign skin lesion that can occur in all age groups and is often seen in individuals with a genetic disposition (e.g., light skin, multiple common moles). The lesion may be flat or raised and is characterized by an asymmetric shape, irregular borders, and inconsistencies in color. The wax-like, greasy appearance of this patient's lesions is not consistent with dysplastic nevi.
questions.hint: The photograph shows the most common benign skin tumor in older patients.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to your clinic with new-onset skin lesions on her face. She is newly married and returned from her honeymoon in South Africa 4 months ago. She reports that the lesions have increased in size since the beginning of the summer. She does not smoke or drink alcohol and takes no medications. On examination, there are skin lesions scattered across her forehead and malar region, with smaller lesions on the nose and above the upper lip. A photograph of her forehead is provided. There are no other lesions elsewhere on her skin. These skin findings are most likely associated with which one of the following?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tinea versicolor, which is caused by the dimorphic fungus Malassezia furfur, can lead to hypopigmented or hyperpigmented macules that can worsen with sun exposure. However, tinea versicolor commonly involves the upper trunk and proximal upper extremities and usually does not manifest on the face. This patient's skin findings are not the result of a fungal infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that typically affects middle-aged women and can manifest with skin lesions on sun-exposed areas. However, patients with SLE typically have a malar erythematous rash with sparing of the nasolabial folds, rather than the hyperpigmented macules seen here. Moreover, individuals with SLE usually have additional symptoms such as arthralgia, fatigue, fever, and/or weight loss. This patient's skin findings are not the result of autoimmunity.

C) INCORRECT:

Atopic dermatitis (AD) and allergic contact dermatitis (ACD) are examples of cutaneous hypersensitivity reactions. In adults, AD can manifest as hyperpigmented lesions, but these lesions are typically found on the flexor surfaces of extremities, not the face, and would be lichenified. Moreover, patients with AD have a history of recurrent flares of pruritic, scaly, erythematous lesions on the face and extensor surfaces during infancy, and on the flexural creases during childhood. ACD caused by UV light (photoallergy), poison ivy (urushiol contact dermatitis), or cosmetic products can affect the face. The history of recent travel and enlargement of the lesions in summer can suggest photoallergy but, as with AD, individuals experiencing a first episode of ACD would have erythematous rather than hyperpigmented macules. It is unlikely that this patient's skin findings are caused by a hypersensitivity reaction.

D) INCORRECT:

Nonclassic congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) and porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) are examples of conditions that are caused by enzyme defects and associated with adult-onset hyperpigmentation. In PCT, hyperpigmentation occurs in sun-exposed regions, such as the face, and it manifests in a melasma-like pattern. However, patients with PCT have a history of increased skin fragility and blistering. The hyperpigmentation of CAH typically occurs in areas that are not sun-exposed, such as the areola, genitalia, axilla, palms, and oral mucous membranes. Moreover, female individuals with nonclassic CAH usually have virilizing features (e.g., hirsutism, androgenic alopecia, acne). It is unlikely that this patient's skin findings are caused by an enzyme defect.

E) CORRECT:

Melasma (chloasma) is a benign disorder characterized by irregular, patchy hyperpigmentation of the skin that is most commonly seen in women of reproductive age, like this patient. Hormonal changes (e.g., pregnancy, oral contraceptive use) seem to play an important role in the development of this condition. Melasma can be triggered and/or exacerbated by exposure to sunlight. Avoiding sunlight and/or applying broad-spectrum sunscreen during pregnancy can prevent or slow the progression of melasma. Topical treatment with depigmenting agents such as hydroxyquinone may be used in severe cases.

Linea nigra and areolar darkening can also develop during pregnancy as a result of endocrine changes but, unlike melasma, these two forms of cutaneous hyperpigmentation are not associated with sun exposure.

Key learning point: Melasma presents as patchy facial hyperpigmentation, often triggered or worsened by pregnancy and sun exposure due to hormonal changes.
questions.hint: The hyperpigmented macules seen in this patient are consistent with melasma.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to your clinic for follow-up. He feels well but is concerned about lesions on his neck that his wife noticed. He is 165 cm tall and weighs 84 kg; BMI is 31. On examination, there are lesions scattered across his neck and axilla. A photograph of the lesions is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Skin tags (acrochordons) are benign outgrowths of normal skin that appear as pedunculated appendices with narrow stalks. The prevalence is 50–60% in individuals aged over 50 years and increases with age. The etiology of skin tags is not fully understood, but they tend to affect areas of the body that experience friction, such as the lower neck, axilla, inframammary fold, and inguinal region. Skin tags are also associated with diabetes and obesity and may be a sign of insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome. Because skin tags are benign lesions, intervention is typically not necessary, but they may be removed for cosmetic purposes using fine-grade scissors, cryosurgery, or electrodesiccation.

Key learning point: Skin tags (acrochordons) are benign, pedunculated skin outgrowths commonly found in areas of friction and are associated with obesity, diabetes, and insulin resistance.

B) INCORRECT:

Dermatofibromas are benign asymptomatic skin lesions that manifest as slow-growing nodules on the skin. In contrast to this patient's lesions, dermatofibromas tend to appear on the lower extremities, are not pedunculated, and do not have a stalk. In addition, dermatofibromas are more common in women, occur at any age, and manifest with a characteristic dimple sign.

C) INCORRECT:

Benign acanthosis nigricans manifests as velvety, hyperpigmented plaques on the skin. Acanthosis nigricans occurs in intertriginous zones (e.g., neck, axial, and/or inframammary fold) and is associated with obesity and diabetes. However, these lesions are associated with symmetrical thickening of the skin and, in some cases, pruritus. Furthermore, they are not pedunculated and do not have a stalk.

D) INCORRECT:

Warts are benign skin lesions resulting from hyperkeratosis and hyperplasia of the epidermis that is typically due to human papillomavirus. In contrast to this patient's lesions, warts manifest as skin-colored, scaly papules/plaques that have a cauliflower-like appearance; they are not pedunculated and do not have a stalk. Common warts occur on the elbows, knees, fingers, and palm while flat warts occur on the face, dorsal hands, and legs, plantar warts on the soles of feet, and anogenital warts on the anus and/or genitals.

E) INCORRECT:

Seborrheic keratosis is a benign outgrowth of keratinocytes and is the most common benign skin tumor in older adults. Lesions can appear on the neck (as with this patient) as well as the trunk, dorsum of the hands, forearms, head, and/or face. However, seborrheic keratosis characteristically manifests as greasy, wax-like papules/plaques that have a “stuck-on” appearance and may become pruritic or bleed easily; they are not pedunculated lesions with a narrow stalk.
questions.hint: The multiple pedunculate appendices with narrow stalks are benign outgrowths of normal skin.

questions.text: You are seeing a 7-year-old girl who is brought to your clinic by her mother because of skin bumps on her right hand. The lesions were first noticed 2 years ago, and at that time, no treatment was given as her previous physician reassured the family that they would resolve spontaneously. The patient is now experiencing teasing at school due to the lesions, and her mother is concerned about the possibility of permanent scarring from the lesions or their treatment. The patient has been otherwise well and her immunizations are up-to-date. She appears scared. A photograph of the lesions is provided. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Surgical excision (e.g., curettage) is a second-line treatment option for the management of common warts. This option is reserved for patients who have not responded to first-line therapy or who request the immediate removal of warts. However, surgery is associated with an increased risk of scarring, infection, and wart recurrence, which limits its use in clinical practice.

B) INCORRECT:

Pulsed dye laser therapy is a second-line treatment option for patients with common warts. Given the high cost, low availability, and side effects of the procedure (e.g., skin discoloration, scarring, pain), pulsed dye laser therapy is reserved for patients who have not responded to first-line therapy. This patient has not yet received any treatment; therefore, another treatment option is indicated at this point.

C) CORRECT:

Topical salicylic acid is one of the first-line treatment options for the management of common warts in patients who present with associated pain, functional impairment, or discomfort. The benefits of this treatment option include high efficacy and availability, low cost, painless application, and minimal side effects, all of which make topical salicylic acid a safe option for wart removal in pediatric patients. Topical salicylic acid can also be combined with other first-line treatment options, such as cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen, for a faster and more effective therapeutic response.

Key learning point: Topical salicylic acid is a safe, effective, and first-line treatment for common warts in children, offering minimal side effects and low risk of scarring.

D) INCORRECT:

Intralesional bleomycin injection may be indicated for patients with common warts that are refractory to first-line treatment. However, this injection is not recommended for immunosuppressed individuals, pregnant women, or children because of the risk of systemic absorption of bleomycin (a chemotherapeutic agent).

E) INCORRECT:

Topical administration of fluorouracil (FU) can be used in patients with common warts who have not responded to first-line treatment. However, topical FU is associated with multiple side effects (e.g., erythema, dryness, burning sensation), and its safety and effectiveness have not been established for pediatric use, making a different intervention more appropriate for this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's partially confluent, hyperkeratotic papules with a rough surface are consistent with common warts, which are caused by human papillomavirus.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man comes to your clinic because his wife is concerned about lesions on his face that she first noticed 4 months ago. He reports feeling well and says the lesions do not cause him any discomfort. He has a 10-year history of hypertension. His family history is unremarkable. His current medications are hydrochlorothiazide and enalapril. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there are two soft, painless, 5-mm papules on the right cheek; a photograph of the lesions is provided. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cryotherapy is the most common treatment for seborrheic keratosis. However, cryotherapy is indicated in symptomatic lesions or if the patient requests treatment for cosmetic reasons, which is not the case here.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical salicylic acid is the first-line treatment for warts, which can manifest as soft papules on the face (i.e., flat warts or verruca plana). However, flat warts are more common in younger individuals and they are usually flesh-colored, smooth, and flat, whereas this elderly patient's lesion is darkly pigmented and has a “stuck-on” appearance. Salicylic acid treatment is not recommended for seborrheic keratosis.

C) INCORRECT:

A shave biopsy might be indicated to rule out malignancy in patients with pigmented skin lesions with atypical features (e.g., size > 6 mm; a recent change in shape, size, or color; irregular borders; asymmetry). This patient, however, has a small (5 mm), asymptomatic lesion that has not changed much over the past 4 months and has a waxy, “stuck-on” appearance, all of which are characteristic of seborrheic keratosis.

D) INCORRECT:

An excisional biopsy is indicated for pigmented lesions if there is suspicion for melanoma. According to the ABCDE rule for melanoma, a biopsy should be considered if the lesion is > 6 mm in diameter, asymmetric, has color variegation, irregular borders, or recent change in size, shape, or color. This patient's lesion has a waxy, “stuck-on” appearance characteristic of seborrheic keratosis, for which biopsy is not routinely indicated.

E) CORRECT:

Seborrheic keratosis is a benign, slow-growing lesion that is commonly seen in older individuals. For asymptomatic lesions, such as the one seen here, treatment is generally not necessary and reassurance with follow-up is sufficient. If atypical features are present (e.g., asymmetry, rapid change or growth, ulceration) or if the diagnosis is unclear, a biopsy may be indicated. Treatment with cryotherapy, laser therapy, or surgical excision is appropriate for cosmetic removal or if the lesion becomes symptomatic (e.g., pruritic, painful, or bleeds easily).

In patients with the sudden appearance of multiple seborrheic keratoses, known as the Leser-Trélat sign, further investigation is necessary because of this feature's association with malignancies such as lung cancer and gastrointestinal cancer.

Key learning point: Seborrheic keratosis is a benign skin lesion in older adults that requires no treatment unless symptomatic or for cosmetic reasons; reassurance and routine follow-up are appropriate.
questions.hint: The photograph shows two sharply demarcated and darkly pigmented papules that have a “stuck-on” appearance. This type of lesion in an older individual is characteristic of seborrheic keratosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of multiple red spots on his trunk. He first noticed these lesions several months ago, and some have increased in size. One day ago, he scratched one of the spots, which bled for several minutes. A photograph of the lesions is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Strawberry angiomas are benign, vascular proliferations that may bleed with trauma, like the lesions seen in this patient. However, strawberry angiomas usually develop in the first weeks of life on the head or neck and then involute by 5–8 years of age.

B) INCORRECT:

Pyogenic granulomas are benign, vascular proliferations that bleed with trauma, like the lesions seen in this patient. However, this condition typically manifests as a solitary papule at sites of trauma (particularly on the face, hands, or mucous membranes), unlike the multiple lesions seen here. Moreover, pyogenic granulomas are more prevalent among children, young adults, and pregnant women.

C) INCORRECT:

Seborrheic keratoses are common, benign skin proliferations with a characteristic greasy, stuck-on appearance. Like this patient's papules, seborrheic keratoses typically develop as multiple lesions on the trunk of adult patients. However, they also commonly develop on the head and extremities. Additionally, these lesions are more commonly brown, tan, or skin-colored and do not bleed with trauma as readily as the lesions seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Cherry angiomas are benign, vascular proliferations that commonly develop in adult patients. The diagnosis is typically made based on the clinical appearance of multiple, bright red, dome-shaped papules on the trunk and upper extremities that bleed with trauma and usually blanch with pressure. These lesions manifest more frequently with age and do not regress. Histologically, they are characterized by dilated interconnecting capillaries within the papillary dermis. No treatment is necessary unless lesions become bothersome (e.g., if they catch on clothing, bleed frequently, or are cosmetically unappealing). Options for removal include electrodessication, laser ablation, and surgical excision.

Key learning point: Cherry angiomas are common, benign vascular papules in adults that appear as bright red, dome-shaped lesions on the trunk and bleed easily with trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Bartonella henselae infections cause bacillary angiomatosis, which manifests with vascular proliferations that bleed with trauma, like the lesions seen in this patient. Although the lesions of bacillary angiomatosis can manifest with a papular appearance, they also commonly manifest as nodular, pedunculated, or verrucous lesions. In addition, this condition usually develops in patients infected with HIV, of which there is no indication here.
questions.hint: This middle-aged man presents with bright red papules that bleed with traumatic rupture, which suggests that the lesions are highly vascular.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to your clinic by his mother because of a dark red mass on his left thumb. The lesion developed after his cat scratched his left thumb and has rapidly increased in size over the past 2 months. It is not painful, but bled profusely once when he accidentally bumped his hand on a desk. He does not take any medications. Vital signs are normal. Examination of the left upper extremity reveals a solitary 2-cm lesion on the interphalangeal joint of the thumb; a photograph of the lesion is provided. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A keloid scar typically develops at the site of a wound 3–12 months after the injury, similar to what is seen in this patient, who was scratched by a cat 6 months ago. However, a keloid scar consists of brownish-red scar tissue with a claw-like appearance that grows beyond the boundaries of the injury, unlike what is seen here. Furthermore, in contrast to this patient's presentation, a keloid scar is usually painful, pruritic, and does not bleed following minor trauma.

B) INCORRECT:

A cherry hemangioma can manifest as a painless, red lesion that may bleed profusely after trauma. However, cherry hemangiomas are usually seen in adults older than 30 years of age and rarely occur on the hands. Moreover, multiple, smaller (0.1–0.4 cm) lesions rather than a single nodule are typically seen.

C) INCORRECT:

A glomus tumor can manifest as a red-purple nodule on the fingers. However, glomus tumors are typically located on the nail bed or the palm and are associated with severe paroxysmal pain, tenderness, and cold sensitivity. Furthermore, a glomus tumor does not usually bleed following minor trauma or develop at the site of an injury.

D) CORRECT:

Pyogenic granuloma (PG) is a benign, vascular tumor characterized by rapid growth and a tendency to bleed profusely after minor trauma. PG typically manifests as a painless, red papule or nodule and often develops at sites of skin injury on the face or hands, as seen here. The exact cause is unknown. Young men and pregnant women are commonly affected. Diagnosis is based on clinical findings but a histopathological confirmation can help to rule out malignant tumors. Surgical excision is the preferred method of treatment because it reduces the recurrence rate. Other methods of treatment include laser therapy, cryotherapy, intralesional steroid injections, and topical therapies (e.g., beta-blockers).

Key learning point: Pyogenic granuloma is a benign, rapidly growing vascular lesion that often develops after skin injury and bleeds easily with minor trauma.

E) INCORRECT:

Kaposi sarcoma can manifest with a painless, red-brown nodule. However, multiple lesions on the lower legs, chest, and/or mucous membranes are typically seen. Moreover, Kaposi sarcoma is typically seen in immunocompromised individuals (e.g., individuals with HIV, organ transplant recipients) and does not usually lead to profuse bleeding following minor trauma.
questions.hint: This condition typically develops following skin trauma.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman comes to your clinic with hyperpigmentation in a masklike distribution over her face (figure). She reports that the discoloration first appeared on her cheeks about 2 years ago and then spread to her upper lip, around her eyes, and onto her forehead. She did not have a preceding rash and has not experienced a similar eruption before. She is otherwise healthy and her only medications are a combined oral contraceptive pill and a multivitamin. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Melasma is a pigmentary disorder characterized by evenly hyperpigmented macules and patches on the face, often affecting the malar cheeks, nose, upper lip, and lower forehead. Women are affected by melasma much more often than men, and onset is usually after puberty. The etiology is unclear. Known risk factors include hyperestrogenism from pregnancy and oral contraceptive use, exposure to ultraviolet radiation, and a positive family history.

Treatment of melasma centers on careful photoprotection. Affected patients should use a broad-spectrum tinted sunscreen to block ultraviolet and visible light, both of which have been linked to worsening disease, and should be encouraged to wear a wide-brim hat. Patients may try compounded creams containing hydroquinone, although they should be counseled to avoid long-term use given the risk for paradoxically worsening hyperpigmentation (exogenous ochronosis). Other treatments for melasma include azelaic acid, kojic acid, chemical peels, fractionated laser therapy, and oral tranexamic acid. Pregnancy-induced melasma is frequently self-limited and may resolve after delivery.

Key learning point: Melasma — an acquired disorder of hyperpigmentation on the cheeks, forehead, nose, and upper lip — is associated with states of elevated estrogen, such as pregnancy and oral contraceptive use.

B) INCORRECT:

Nevus of Ota represents facial dermal melanocytosis that is usually seen at birth but is occasionally noted after puberty or pregnancy. It often has a blue-gray color because the pigment is dermal rather than epidermal.

C) INCORRECT:

Lentigo maligna, a subtype of melanoma in situ on the face, manifests with irregular borders and color variegation. Even pigmentation and symmetric distribution on the face would not be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Postinflammatory hyperpigmentation refers to hyperpigmentation at sites of previous inflammation or trauma. The lack of antecedent rash or trauma in this patient makes this diagnosis less likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Lentigines are acquired hyperpigmented macules and patches related to increased melanocyte-derived melanin production. However, lesions associated with this diagnosis are usually much smaller than the patches on the upper lip of this patient.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman comes to your clinic for an annual health maintenance examination. She reports feeling well. She is 155 cm tall and weighs 79 kg; BMI is 33. On examination, there is a skin rash over both axillae. A photograph of her left axilla is provided. This skin finding is most likely associated with which one of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, which manifests with a symmetrical, thickened, and hyperpigmented rash. However, the rash typically occurs in areas of the skin exposed to the sunlight (e.g., face, neck, hands) rather than in the axillae, as seen here. Moreover, further symptoms of pellagra, such as vomiting, diarrhea, atrophic glossitis, and neurological symptoms are absent in this patient. Niacin deficiency is not associated with acanthosis nigricans.

Pellagra and acanthosis nigricans can both manifest with a collar around the neck; also referred to as Casal necklace in the case of pellagra. However, the skin in niacin deficiency looks sun-burnt rather than velvety as seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Primary adrenal insufficiency (Addison disease) presents with hyperpigmented skin lesions caused by the stimulant effects of excess ACTH on the melanocytes which produce melanin (bronze disease). Unlike the skin finding in this patient, the hyperpigmentation in Addison disease is typically generalized and often involves the palm creases or oral mucosa. Instead of obesity, patients with Addison disease present with weight loss and anorexia due to hypocortisolism. Lastly, the absence of other symptoms such as hypotension and intestinal complaints (nausea, vomiting, and/or diarrhea), make Addison disease unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Pregnancy is associated with hyperpigmentation due to increased melanocyte-stimulating hormone produced by the placenta. Although the axillae may be affected, hyperpigmentation of the linea alba, the nipples, areola, and the face (i.e., melasma) are far more common. Moreover, the hyperpigmented macules and patches often seen during pregnancy are not thickened and velvety as seen here. Pregnancy is not associated with acanthosis nigricans.

D) CORRECT:

Acanthosis nigricans is commonly seen in disorders characterized by insulin resistance and hyperinsulinemia (e.g., polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), obesity, diabetes mellitus, acromegaly). Elevated levels of insulin stimulate keratinocyte and dermal fibroblast proliferation via interaction with insulin-like growth factor 1, resulting in epidermal hyperplasia and plaque-like lesions. In addition, insulin resistance in PCOS is responsible for hyperandrogenism (leading to acne, hirsutism) and anovulation (causing amenorrhea and impaired fertility).

Similar skin changes can be caused by obesity alone, in which case the disorder is referred to as pseudoacanthosis nigricans.

Key learning point: Acanthosis nigricans, characterized by thickened, velvety hyperpigmented skin in body folds, is commonly associated with insulin resistance seen in conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome and obesity.

E) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal malignancies can manifest with acanthosis nigricans. However, if this skin finding occurs in association with a malignancy, such as paraneoplastic syndrome, it is characterized by rapid onset, a verrucous or papulous surface, and involvement of atypical sites (e.g., palms, soles, or mucous membranes), which is not the case in this patient. Moreover, malignant acanthosis nigricans is associated with gastric adenocarcinoma, not gastric malignant lymphoma. Lastly, gastric cancer is rare in young adults and this woman has no signs of gastrointestinal malignancy such as weight loss, anemia, abdominal discomfort, or melena.
questions.hint: The picture shows acanthosis nigricans, a skin condition that manifests with thickened, velvety, hyperpigmented plaques and most frequently involves intertriginous sites such as the axillae or the neck.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to your clinic with asymptomatic hyperpigmentation around her neck and in both axillae (see figure). She first noticed these changes about 3 years ago and is concerned about their appearance. She has no significant medical history and takes no medications. Her BMI is 32. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying condition associated with these skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nutritional deficiencies, such as zinc deficiency, can manifest as skin rashes. The typical findings of zinc deficiency are dry, scaly, sharply demarcated plaques on the face or groin. Rashes associated with zinc deficiency can resolve rapidly with zinc supplementation. Acanthosis nigricans is not specifically associated with zinc deficiency.

B) INCORRECT:

Fungal infections, such as tinea corporis, manifest as annular (ring-shaped), scaling plaques. Tinea corporis is caused by a dermatophyte infection and is not associated with acanthosis nigricans.

C) CORRECT:

Acanthosis nigricans is a skin disorder characterized by symmetric, hyperpigmented, velvety plaques on flexural areas (e.g., neck, axillae, groin). It is usually asymptomatic but may also be pruritic.

Acanthosis nigricans is commonly associated with insulin resistance or type 2 diabetes. The exact pathophysiology is unknown but may involve the stimulation of insulin-like growth factor receptors and tyrosine kinase receptors on keratinocytes and fibroblasts. Given that obesity is a risk factor for insulin resistance, acanthosis nigricans may also occur in people with obesity.

Acanthosis nigricans has been associated with endocrinopathies such as hypercortisolism and growth hormone excess. Other less common associations with acanthosis nigricans include use of certain medications (e.g., niacin) and malignancy, especially in people who have extensive and sudden onset of acanthosis nigricans.

Key learning point: Acanthosis nigricans appears as hyperpigmented, velvety plaques, typically in flexural areas, and is commonly associated with insulin resistance.

D) INCORRECT:

Although acanthosis nigricans has been associated with endocrinopathies such as hypercortisolism and growth hormone excess, it is not typically associated with thyroid disease.

E) INCORRECT:

Atopic dermatitis may cause thickening and hyperpigmentation of the skin — called lichen simplex chronicus — when the rash is chronically scratched. Unlike acanthosis nigricans, lichen simplex chronicus tends to be pruritic and to have associated scaling and excoriation; in addition, the axillae would be an atypical location for atopic dermatitis. Although atopic dermatitis can lead to lichen simplex chronicus, it is not classically associated with acanthosis nigricans.
